Directions: Read the passage and then answer each question. There are three underlined words or phrases in the passage to show which word or phrase may be incorrect.
Content: Have you ever thought about getting a job as an ice cream taster when you grow up? It might sound too good to be true, b͟u͟t ice cream tasters get paid to do just that.

The job is more difficult than just eating ice cream all day, though. John Harrison is a master taster. This means that he has been sampling the sweet stuff for a long time. For more than thirty years, Harrison has sampled up to thirty different flavors of ice cream each day. Tasters like Harrison have to consider the texture of each flavor, in addition to s͟m͟e͟l͟l͟,͟ ͟c͟o͟l͟o͟r͟,͟ ͟a͟n͟d͟ ͟a͟p͟p͟e͟a͟r͟a͟n͟c͟e͟.

If ice cream tasters are lucky, they can even get an o͟p͟o͟r͟t͟u͟n͟i͟t͟y to suggest new flavors. Harrison is always trying to think of the next great ice cream flavor. He even sleeps with a pencil and paper beside his bed, just in case he dreams up something delicious.
